By HARRY LAMBRIGHT

In an effort to relieve Dr. G. Wilson Shaffer, Dean
of the Homewood Schools, of the time-consuming scholarship responsibilities he has undertaken previously, and
to centralize under one man all authority for administering financial aid to students, Mr. William F. Logan, Dean
of Admissions, will in the future also regulate student
scholarships and loans.
In addition, Dr. W. Kelso Morrill, Professor of Mathematics,
will add to his responsibilities as
Director of Student Activities the
position of Dean of Students.
This second role marks an
effort on the part of the Hopkins administration to give Dr.
Morrill an opportunity to participate more widely in the area
of student affairs. He will coordinate all activities of student
groups, clubs, and other organized activities of the undergraduate students.
Retain Authority
Although both Mr. Logan and
Dr. Morrill will continue to report directly to Dean Shaffer,
they will retain almost complete
authority in the areas designated
to them.
With Mr. Logan shifting his
attention to scholarship matters,
his assistant Mr. Robert Bilgrave
will take charge of the majority
of the admissions details and
will be aided by Mr. Howard
Snethan and a new man to be
added to the admissions staff
later.
Directly In Charge
Mr. Logan's new duties will
place him directly in charge of
student loans and scholarship
and fellowship grants for both
the graduate and the undergraduate students. He will serve
ex officio on all committees dealing with aid to students; he will
work with Lyon Rogers, Placement Bureau Director, to assure
the most deserving students of
first opportunity for employment; and he will attempt to
interview all students applying
for financial aid.

ROTC Staff
Loses Brass
Three officers of the Johns
Hopkins University ROTC cadre
have been reassigned duty in the
normal rotation of Army personnel. All three are scheduled
to depart prior to the re-opening
of school in September.
The three officers scheduled
for transfer are Colonel James
0. Clay, Major Joseph Spinelli
and Captain Robert Peach.
Colonel Clay has been assigned to the Far East Command
and will depart sometime in
September. He will be replaced
by Colonel D. M. Cheston, III,
who will arrive in mid-August
from his present post in the U.S.
Army mission at Bogata, Columbia. Both are Infantry officers.
Major Spinelli also will go to
the Far East. He is to depart
in late June, but no replacement
has yet been announced.
Captain Peach is scheduled to
depart in September for his new
post in Europe. Captain William
M. Thornton, who, like Peach, is
in the Corps of Engineers, will
arrive at Hopkins late in June.
Recently departed from the
Hopkins R.O.T.C. staff, M/Sgt.
Charles Shelby is enrolled in the
Army Language School, Monterey, California as prelude to
assignment in Guatemala.

A program for grading faculty salary scales in institutions of higher education has been developed for the
American Association of University Professors by a special sub-committee of the Association.
The plan will grade institutions on an AA, A, B, C,
D, E and F basis according to the minimum salary scale
for full, associate and assistant professors, and full-time
instructors.
Although Johns Hopkins has not released data about
its maximum or minimum salary scale—only its average
salaries—there is speculation from authoritative sources
that the University would rank in the "E" category in
minimum salaries.

University Adds Two Men
To Philosophy Department
The Johns Hopkins University
recently announced the appointment of two new men to the
Department of Philosophy. They
are Dr. Joseph S. Ulian and Dr.
Harold A. McNitt.
Dr. Ulian will join the faculty
as Assistant Professor. He was
born in 1930 and graduated
"cum laude" from Harvard in
1952. While there, he studied
mathematical ("symbolic") logic
under the celebrated Dr. W. V.
Quine. He is presently connected
with the Department of Philosophy at Stanford University in
California.
Dr. Vernon A. Lowe, head of
the Hopkins Philosophy Department, told the News-Letter this
week, "Dr. Ulian as a research
specialist will fill a void in the
staff left in 1884 when Charles
S. Peirsce was' at Hopkins as a
lecturer in logic. At that time
Hopkins was the first university
to have such a field as mathe-

matical logic. Since Dr. Peirsce
retired no one in this type of
research has taught at the University." Dr. Ulian will teach
courses in symbolic logic in
addition to his research.
Dr. McNitt will come to Hopkins as an instructor. He received his Ph.D. from the University of Michigan in 1956, and
was recently awarded a Fulbright.
Scholarship to Sweden where he
has been working on his predoctorate at the University of
Copenhagen.
Dr. McNitt will teach a
field of social and political
philosophy. While in Sweden
he observed the country and
people in relation to his theoretical study.
Mr. McNitt will teach a
special 300-level course next year
for undergraduates interested in
Political theory. The remainder
of his teaching will be on the
graduate level.

Last week we passed along some fashion hints for
coeds. Today we will do the same for college men.
The most important thing to remember, gentlemen,
is to dress with verve, with dash, with inventiveness.
Don't be imprisoned by the traditional conservatism
of men's clothing. Brighten up your appearance with
a single earring, or a cavalry saber, or a gold derby.

Last week we passed along some fashion hints for
coeds. Today we will do the same for college men.
The most important thing to remember, gentlemen,
is to dress with verve, with dash, with inventiveness.

Two months ago this column ran a series explaining

of information since March 7!
For a school that "stresses" wide participation, the
intramural athletic program at Hopkins is weak. If it
Weren't for the fraternity leagues, the whole program
Would probably fold up.
We feel that the fault lies more with the Board of
Intramural Athletics than with either the Athletic DePartment or the student body.

independent sports has been negligible. And most of those
Participating have been fraternity men.
If electing freshmen for a four year term on the Board
IS responsible for the members' feeling of complacency,
We question the advisability of such a practice. There are
Others on campus that are interested in promoting the
intramural sports and would work to stimulate interest
in the program if they were given the chance.
